entities.name: Music Theory Overview
entities.value: Overview of music theory concepts including pitch, scales, intervals, chords, harmony, rhythm, form, notation, counterpoint, and modern extensions.
entities.description: Provided a concise guide to main concepts of music theory as requested by the user.

entities.name: UI style preference
entities.value: MonsterUI tabs
entities.description: User prefers MonsterUI-style tabbed documents for presenting information

entities.name: Markdown tab support
entities.value: Markdown does not have built-in tab syntax; tabs require HTML, extensions, or platform-specific widgets.
entities.description: Core Markdown lacks tab UI components; workarounds include raw HTML/CSS, extensions, JavaScript widgets, or third‑party services.

entities.name: Music Theory Tabbed Markdown
entities.value: Self‑contained Markdown with HTML/CSS tabs presenting music‑theory concepts (Pitch & Notes, Scales & Modes, Intervals, Chords & Harmony, Progressions & Cadences, Rhythm & Meter, Form, Notation, Counterpoint & Voice Leading, Modern Extensions).
entities.description: Markdown document using raw HTML and CSS to create MonsterUI‑style tabbed sections for music theory concepts.

entities.name: Music Theory Concepts Table
entities.value: Table of core music theory concepts with brief descriptions
entities.description: Provides a concise table outlining core music theory concepts: Pitch & Notes, Scales & Modes, Intervals, Chords, Harmony, Progressions, Rhythm & Meter, Form, Notation, Counterpoint, Modern Extensions.

entities.name: MonsterUI Approach for Music Theory
entities.value: Detailed plan to use MonsterUI components (tabs, accordion, carousel, slider, interactive diagram, matrix grid, flowchart, sortable table, metronome widget, timeline slider, rich text editor, dual‑staff editor, video embed, etc.) to create an interactive learning hub for music theory concepts.
entities.description: Assistant's proposed approach to expand the music theory table using the full suite of MonsterUI UI components, mapping each concept to specific components for interactive learning.

entities.name: Chord progressions video
entities.value: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yI9MVYdoUT4
entities.description: Short, highly‑rated YouTube video explaining chord progressions (3 min30 sec, 87 likes).

entities.name: Bee flight myth (1930s)
entities.value: Early aerodynamic calculations suggested honey‑bees should be unable to fly.
entities.description: In the 1930s French entomologists Antoine Magnan and André Sainte‑Lague used steady‑flow aerodynamics and concluded that a honey‑bee’s tiny wings could not generate enough lift, creating the popular myth that bees shouldn’t be able to fly.

entities.name: Bee wing‑beat frequency
entities.value: Honey‑bees flap about 230 times per second.
entities.description: High‑speed imaging shows honey‑bees beating their wings at roughly 230 Hz, far faster than larger insects, contributing to unsteady aerodynamic lift.

entities.name: Bee stroke arc
entities.value: Bee wings move through an approximate 90° arc each stroke.
entities.description: Instead of a full half‑circle sweep, a bee’s wings travel a short, choppy 90° arc before reversing direction, concentrating aerodynamic forces.

entities.name: Bee rapid wing rotation
entities.value: Each stroke includes a quick flip‑over of the wing, producing impulsive acceleration of air.
entities.description: The rapid rotation at the end of each stroke creates a strong, short‑duration lift impulse that a steady‑flow model does not capture.

entities.name: Leading‑edge vortex (LEV) in bee flight
entities.value: LEVs form on the front edge of bee wings, creating low‑pressure regions that boost lift.
entities.description: During each stroke a tiny tornado‑like vortex forms on the wing’s leading edge, allowing the wing to be angled more sharply and dramatically increasing lift.

entities.name: Flexible wing hinge in bees
entities.value: Bee wings can change angle from ~135° to ~235° via a flexible hinge.
entities.description: A flexible hinge between fore‑ and hind‑wings lets bees vary their wing angle dramatically during each stroke, further increasing lift and drag compared with rigid wings.

entities.name: Resulting lift generation in bee flight
entities.value: Unsteady lift bursts each stroke support the bee’s weight, even when carrying nectar.
entities.description: The combination of high‑frequency flapping, short‑arc motion, LEVs, and flexible wing articulation produces large, impulsive lift forces that keep the bee aloft.

entities.name: Persistence of the bee‑flight myth
entities.value: The myth persists because it illustrates limits of macroscopic aerodynamic intuition.
entities.description: The story remains popular as a cautionary tale that intuition based on large‑scale aerodynamics can fail for tiny, rapidly moving objects; modern research resolved the paradox with high‑speed photography and robotic wing models.

entities.name: Pull‑up progression plan
entities.value: Step‑by‑step training program to move from 7 pull‑ups to a full muscle‑up (hang, swing, and touch the bar with feet). Includes foundations, explosiveness, core/hip‑hinge work, transition drills, weekly schedule, and success tips.
entities.description: Detailed fitness plan provided to the user, organized in MonsterUI‑style tabbed sections, covering grip strength, pull‑up volume, kipping swings, hanging leg‑to‑bar, transition drills, and recovery advice.

entities.name: Pull‑up progression video
entities.value: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9Le9gdYGtBg
entities.description: Short, highly‑rated YouTube video guiding through the pull‑up‑to‑muscle‑up progression (grip, explosive pull, kip, dip).

entities.name: Python programming language
entities.value: Python is a high‑level, general‑purpose programming language that emphasizes readability and simplicity, uses an interpreter to execute code line‑by‑line, supports dynamic typing, and includes a large standard library that provides ready‑made modules for tasks such as file handling, networking, data processing, and more.
entities.description: Python is a high‑level, general‑purpose programming language that emphasizes readability and simplicity. It uses an interpreter to execute code line‑by‑line, which lets you run programs without a separate compilation step. The language supports dynamic typing, meaning you don’t have to declare variable types explicitly, and it includes a large standard library that provides ready‑made modules for common tasks such as file handling, networking, data processing, and more.
